sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Never talk to me, I will weep.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Do I prithee, but yet have the grace to consider,
that tears do not become a man.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But have I not cause to weep?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
As good cause as one would desire,
Therefore weep.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
His very hair
Is of the dissembling colour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Something browner than Judases:
Marry his kisses are Judas' children.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'faith his hair is of a good colour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
An excellent colour:
Your Chestnut was ever the only colour:

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
And his kissing is as full of sanctity,
As the touch of holy bread.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana: a
Nun of winters sisterhood kisses not more religiously,
the very ice of chastity is in them.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p:
But why did he swear he would come this
morning, and comes not?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay certainly there is no truth in him.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Yes, I think he is not a pick purse, nor a horse- stealer,
but for his verity in love, I do think him as
concave as a covered goblet, or a Worm-eaten nut.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Not true in love?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Yes, when he is in, but I think he is not in.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You have heard him swear downright he was.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Was, is not is: besides, the oath of Lover is no
stronger than the word of a Tapster, they are both the
confirmer of false reckonings, he attends here in the forest
on the Duke your father.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I met the Duke yesterday, and had much question
with him: he asked me of what parentage I was; I
told him of as good as he, so he laughed and let me go.
But what talk we of Fathers, when there is such a man
as Orlando?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
O that is a brave man, he writes brave verses,
speaks brave words, swears brave oaths, and breaks
them bravely, quite travers athwart the heart of his lover,
as a puny Tilter, that
spurs his horse but on one side, breaks his staff like a noble goose; but all is brave that
youth mounts, and folly guides: who comes here?

sp.speaker: Corin.
sp.l: Mistress and Master, you have oft enquired
After the Shepherd that complained of love,
Who you saw sitting by me on the Turf,
Praising the proud disdainful Shepherdess
That was his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well: and what of him?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: If you will see a pageant truly played
Between the pale complexion of true Love,
And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,
Go hence a little, and I shall conduct you
If you will mark it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O come, let us remove,
The sight of lovers feedeth those in love:
Bring us to this sight, and you shall say
I will prove a busy actor in their play.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sweet Phebe do not scorn me, do not Phebe
Say that you love me not, but say not so
In bitterness; the common executioner
Whose heart the accustomed sight of death makes hard
Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck,
But first begs pardon: will you sterner be
Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: I would not be thy executioner,
I fly thee, for I would not injure thee:
Thou tellest me there is murder in mine eye,
It is pretty sure, and very probable,
That eyes that are the frailest, and softest things,
Who shut their coward gates on atomies,
Should be called tyrants, butchers, murtherers.
Now I do frown on thee with all my heart,
And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee:
Now counterfeit to swoon, why now fall down,
Or if thou canst not, O for shame, for shame,
Lie not, to say mine eyes are murtherers:
Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee,
Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains
Some scar of it: Lean upon a rush
The Cicatrice and capable impressure
Thy palm some moment keeps: but now mine eyes
Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not,
Nor I am sure there is no force in eyes
That can do hurt.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O dear Phebe,
If ever (as that ever may be near)
You meet in some fresh check the power of fancy,
Then shall you know the wounds invisible
That Loves keen arrows make.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: But till that time
Come not thou near me: and when that time comes,
Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not,
As till that time I shall not pity thee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And why I pray you? who might be your mother
That you insult, exult, and all at once
Over the wretched? what though you have no beauty
As by my faith, I see no more in you
than without Candle may go dark to bed:
Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?
Why what means this? why do you look on me?
I see no more in you than in the ordinary
Of Natures sale-work? 'ods my little life,
I think she means to tangle my eyes too:
No faith proud Mistress, hope not after it,
It is not your inky brows, your black silk hair,
Your bugle eye-balls, nor your cheek of cream
That can tame my spirits to your worship:
You foolish Shepherd, wherefore do you follow her
Like foggy South puffing with wind and rain,
You are a thousand times a properer man
Than she a woman. It is such fools as you
That makes the world full of ill-favoured children:
It is not her glass, but you that flatters her,
And out of you she sees herself more proper
Than any of her lineaments can show her:
But Mistress, know yourself, down on your knees
And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love;
For I must tell you friendly in your ear,
Sell when you can, you are not for all markets:
Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer,
Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.
So take her to thee Shepherd, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Sweet youth, I pray you chide a year together,
I had rather hear you chide, than this man woo.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: He is fallen in love with your foulness, and she will
Fall in love with my anger. If it be so, as fast
As she answers thee with frowning looks, I will sauce
Her with bitter words: why look you so upon me?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: For no ill will I bear you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I pray you do not fall in love with me,
For I am falser than vows made in wine:
Besides, I like you not: if you will know my house,
It is at the tuft of Olives, here hard by:
Will you go Sister? Shepherd ply her hard:
Come Sister: Shepherdess, look on him better
And be not proud, though all the world could see,
None could be so abused in sight as he.
Come, to our flock,

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Dead Shepherd, now I find thy saw of might,
Who ever loved, that loved not at first sight?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sweet Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Ha: what sayst thou Siluius?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sweet Phebe pity me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Why I am sorry for thee gentle Siluius.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Wherever sorrow is, relief would be:
If you do sorrow at my grief in love,
By giving love your sorrow, and my grief
Were both exterminated.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Thou hast my love, is not that neighbourly?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I would have you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Why that were covetousness:
Siluius; the time was, that I hated thee;
And yet it is not, that I bear thee love,
But since that thou canst talk of love so well,
Thy company, which erst was irksome to me
I will endure; and I will employ thee too:
But do not look for further recompense
than thine own gladness, that thou art employed.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: So holy, and so perfect is my love,
And I in such a poverty of grace,
That I shall think it a most plenteous crop
To glean the broken ears after the man
That the main harvest reaps: lose now and then
A scattered smile, and that I will live upon.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Knowest thou the youth that spoke to me yerewhile?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Not very well, but I have met him oft,
And he hath bought the Cottage and the bounds
That the old Carlot once was Master of.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: think not I love him, though I ask for him,
It is but a peevish boy, yet he talks well,
But what care I for words? yet words do well
When he that speaks them pleases those that hear:
It is a pretty youth, not very pretty,
But sure he is proud, and yet his pride becomes him;
He will make a proper man: the best thing in him
Is his complexion: and faster than his tongue
Did make offence, his eye did heal it up:
He is not very tall, yet for his years he is tall:
His leg is but so so, and yet it is well:
There was a pretty redness in his lip,
A little riper, and more lusty red
Than that mixed in his cheek: it was just the difference
Betwixt the constant red, and mingled Damask.
There be some women Siluius, had they marked him
In parcels as I did, would have gone near
To fall in love with him: but for my part
I love him not, nor hate him not: and yet
Have more cause to hate him than to love him,
For what had he to do to chide at me?
He said mine eyes were black, and my hair black,
And now I am remembered, scorned at me:
I marvel why I answered not again,
But that is all one: omittance is no quittance:
I will write to him a very taunting Letter,
And thou salt bear it, wilt thou Siluius?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Phebe, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: I will write it strait;
The matter is in my head, and in my heart,
I will be bitter with him, and passing short;
Go with me Siluius.

div2.head:
Actus Quartus.
Scene Prima.
div2.stage: Enter Rosalind, and Celia, and Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Aye prithee, pretty youth, let me better acquainted
with thee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I am so: I do love it better than laughing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Those that are in extremity of either, are abominable
fellows, and betray themselves to every modern
censure, worse than drunkards.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Why, it is good to be sad and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Why then it is good to be a post.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
I have neither the Scholars melancholy, which
is emulation: nor the Musicians, which is fantastical;
nor the Courtiers, which is proud: nor the Soldiers,
which is ambitious: nor the Lawyers, which is politic:
nor the Ladies, which is nice: nor the Lovers, which
is all these: but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded
of many simples, extracted from many objects,
and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels, in
which by often rumination, wraps me in a most humorous
sadness.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
A Traveller: by my faith you have great reason
to be sad: I fear you have sold your own Lands,
to see other men's; then to have seen much, and to have
nothing, is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Yes, I have gained my experience.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
And your experience makes you sad: I had rather
have a fool to make me merry, than experience to
make me sad, and to travail for it too.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Good day, and happiness, dear Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Nay then God buy you, and you talk in blank
verse.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Farewell Monsieur Traveller: look you
lisp, and wear strange suites; disable all the benefits
of your own Country: be out of love with your
nativity, and almost chide God for making you that
countenance you are; or I will scarce think you have
swam in a Gundello. Why how now Orlando, where
have you been all this while? you a lover? and you
serve me such another trick, never come in my sight
more.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my
promise.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Break an hours promise in love? he that
will divide a minute into a thousand parts, and break
but a part of the thousand part of a minute in the affairs
of love, it may be said of him that Cupid hath clapped
him on the shoulder, but I will warrant him heart hole.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pardon me dear Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Nay, if you be so tardy, come no more in my
sight, I had as lief be wooed of a Snail.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Of a Snail?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Aye, of a Snail: for though he comes slowly, he
carries his house on his head; a better jointure I think
than you make a woman: besides, he brings his destiny
with him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Why horns: which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for: but he comes armed in his
fortune, and prevents the slander of his wife.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is
virtuous.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And I am your Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
It pleases him to call you so: but he hath a Rosalind
of a better leer than you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Come, woo me, woo me: for now I am in a
holy-day humour, and like enough to consent: What
would you say to me now, if I were your very, very
Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I would kiss before I spoke.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Nay, you were better speak first, and when you
were gravelled, for lack of matter, you might take occasion
to kiss: very good Orators when they are out,
they will spit, and for lovers, lacking (God warn us )
matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: How if the kiss be denied?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins
new matter.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Who could be out, being before his beloved
Mistress?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Marry that should you if I were your Mistress,
or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What, of my suite?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your
suite:
Am not I your Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I take some joy to say you are, because I would
be talking of her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Well, in her person, I say I will not have you.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then in mine own person, I die.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
No faith, die by Attorney: the poor world is
almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there
was not any man died in his own person ( videlicet ) in
a love cause: Troilous had his brains dashed out with a
Grecian club, yet he did what he could to die before,
and he is one of the patterns of love. Leander, he would
have lived many a fair year though Hero had turned
Nun; if it had not been for a hot Midsummer-night, for
(good youth) he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont,
and being taken with the cramp, was drowned,
and the foolish Chroniclers of that age, found it was
Hero of Cestos. But these are all lies, men have died
from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not
for love.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind,
for I protest her frown might kill me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
By this hand, it will not kill a fly: but come,
now I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition:
and ask me what you will, I will grant it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then love me Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes faith will I, fridays and saturdays, and all.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And wilt thou have me?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Aye, and twenty such.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Are you not good?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Rosalind.
sp.p:
Why then, can one desire too much of a
good thing: Come sister, you shall be the Priest, and
marry us: give me your hand Orlando: What do you
say sister?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pray thee marry us.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I cannot say the words.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You must begin, will you Orlando.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Go too: will you Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Aye, but when?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Why now, as fast as she can marry us.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Then you must say, I take thee Rosalind for
wife.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I take thee Rosalind for wife.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I might ask you for your Commission,
But I do take thee Orlando for my husband: there is a
girl goes before the Priest, and certainly a Woman's
thought runs before her actions.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: So do all thoughts, they are winged.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Now tell me how long you would have her, after
you have possessed her?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: For ever, and a day.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Say a day, without the ever: no, no Orlando, men
are April when they woe, December when they wed:
Maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes
when they are wives: I will be more jealous of
thee, than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen, more
clamorous than a Parrot against rain, more new-fangled
than an ape, more giddy in my desires, than a monkey:
I will weep
for nothing, like Diana in the Fountain,
and I will do that when you are disposed to be merry:
I will laugh like a Hyena, and that when thou art inclined
to sleep.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: But will my Rosalind do so?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: By my life, she will do as I do.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: O but she is wise.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Or else she could not have the wit to do this:
the wiser, the waywarder: make the doors upon a woman's
wit, and it will out at the casement: shut that, and
it will out at the key-hole: stop that, it will fly with the
smoke out at the chimney.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might
say, wit whether wilt?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you
met your wives wit going to your neighbours bed.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And what wit could wit have, to excuse that?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Marry to say, she came to seek you there: you
shall never take her without her answer, unless you take
her without her tongue: O that woman that cannot
make her fault her husbands occasion, let her never nurse
her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: For these two hours Rosalinde, I will leave thee.

sp.speaker: Ros
sp.p: Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I must attend the Duke at dinner; by two a clock
I will be with thee again.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
aye, go your ways, go your ways: I knew what
you would prove, my friends told me as much, and I
thought no less: that flattering tongue of yours won
me: it is but one cast away, and so come death: two o'clock
is your hour.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Aye, sweet Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God
mend me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous,
if you break one jot of your promise, or come one
minute behind your hour, I will think you the most
pathetical break-promise, and the most hollow lover,
and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalinde, that
may be chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful:
therefore beware my censure, and keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
With no less religion, than if thou wert indeed
my Rosalind: so adieu.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Well, Time is the old Justice that examines all
such offenders, and let time try: adieu.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate:
we must have your doublet and hose plucked over
your head, and show the world what the bird hath done
to her own nest.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
O cuz, cuz, cuz: my pretty little cuz, that thou
didst know how many fathom deep I am in love: but
it cannot be sounded: my affection hath an unknown
bottom, like the Bay of Portugall.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Or rather bottomless, that as fast as you pour
affection in, in runs out.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
No, that same wicked Bastard of Venus, that was
begot of thought, conceived of spleen, and born of
madness, that blind rascally boy, that abuses every
ones eyes, because his own are out, let him be judge,
how deep I am in love: I will tell thee Aliena, I cannot be
out of the sight of Orlando: I will go find a shadow, and
sigh till he come.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And I will sleep.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Which is he that killed the Dear?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir, it was I.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Let us present him to the Duke like a Roman
Conqueror, and it would do well to set the Deers
horns upon his head, for a branch of victory; have you
no song Forester for this purpose?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Sing it: it is no matter how it be in tune, so it
make noise enough.

sp.l: What shall he have that killed the Dear?
His Leather skin, and horns to wear:
Then sing him home the rest shall bear this burthen;
Take thou no scorn to wear the horn,
It was a crest ere thou wast born,
Thy fathers father wore it,
And thy father bore it.
The horn, the horn, the lusty horn,
Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: How say you now, is it not past two a clock?
And here much Orlando.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I warrant you, with pure love, and troubled brain,
sp.l: He hath taken his bow and arrows, and is gone forth
To sleep: look who comes here.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My errand is to you, fair youth,
My gentle Phebe, did bid me give you this:
I know not the contents, but as I guess
By the stern brow, and waspish action
Which she did use, as she was writing of it,
It bears an angry tenure; pardon me,
I am but as a guiltless messenger.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Patience herself would startle at this letter,
And play the swaggerer, bear this, bear all:
She says I am not fair, that I lack manners,
She calls me proud, and that she could not love me
Were man as rare as Phoenix: God is my will,
Her love is not the Hare that I do hunt,
Why writes she so to me? well Shepherd, well,
This is a Letter of your own device.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: No, I protest, I know not the contents,
Phebe did write it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Come, come, you are a fool,
And turned into the extremity of love.
I saw her hand, she has a leathern hand,
A freestone coloured hand: I verily did think
That her old gloves were on, but it was her hands:
She has a housewives hand, but that is no matter:
I say she never did invent this letter,
This is a man's invention, and his hand.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sure it is hers.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why, it is a boisterous and a cruel style,
A style for challengers: why, she defies me,
Like Turk to Christian: womens gentle brain
Could not drop forth such giant rude invention,
Such Ethiop words, blacker in their effect
Then in their countenance: will you hear the letter?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: So please you, for I never heard it yet:
Yet heard too much of Phebes cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes.

sp.l: Art thou god, to Shepherd turned?
That a maidens heart hath burned.

sp.p: Can a woman rail thus?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Call you this railing?

sp.l: Why, thy godhead laid a part,
Warest thou with a woman's heart?

sp.p: Did you ever hear such railing?

sp.l: Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
That could do no vengeance to me.

sp.p: Meaning me a beast.

sp.l: If the scorn of your bright eyen
have power to raise such love in mine,
Alack, in me, what strange effect
Would they work in mild aspect?
Whiles you chid me, I did love,
How then might your prayers move?
He that brings this love to thee,
Little knows this Love in me:
And by him seal up thy mind,
Whether that thy youth and kind
Will the faithful offer take
Of me, and all that I can make,
Or else by him my love deny,
And then I will study how to die.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Call you this chiding?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Alas poor Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
do you pity him? No, he deserves no pity:
wilt thou love such a woman? what to make thee an instrument,
and play false strains upon thee? not to be endured.
Well, go your way to her; (for I see Love hath
made thee a tame snake) and say this to her; That if she
love me, I charge her to love thee: if she will not, I will
never have her, unless thou entreat for her: if you be a
true over hence, and not a word; for here comes more
company.

sp.speaker: Oliu.
sp.l: Good morrow, fair ones: pray you, (if you know)
Where in the Purlieus of this Forest, stands
A sheep-coat, fenced about with Olive-trees.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: West of this place, down in the neighbour bottom
The rank of Osiers, by the murmuring stream
Left on your right hand, brings you to the place:
But at this hour, the house doth keep itself
There is none within.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
Then should I know you by description,
Such garments, and such years: the boy is fair,
Of female favour, and bestows himself
Like a ripe sister: the woman low
And browner than her brother: are not you
The owner of the house I did enquire for?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is no boast, being asked, to say we are.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Orlando doth commend him to you both,
And to that youth he calls his Rosalind,
He sends this bloody napkin; are you he?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am: what must we understand by this?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Some of my shame, if you will know of me
What man I am, and how, and why, and where
This handkercher was stained.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I pray you tell it.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: When last the young Orlando parted from you,
He left a promise to return again
Within an hour, and pacing through the Forest,
Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
Lo what befell: he threw his eye aside,
And mark what object did present itself
Under an old Oak, whose bows were mossed with age
And high top, bald with dry antiquity:
A wretched ragged man, overgrown with hair
Lay sleeping on his back; about his neck
A green and gilded snake had wreathed itself,
Who with her head, nimble in threats approached
The opening of his mouth: but suddenly
Seeing Orlando, it unlinked itself,
And with indented glides, did slip away
Into a bush, undr which bushes shade
A Lioness, with udders all drawn dry,
Lay couching head on ground, with cat-like watch
When that the sleeping man should stir; for it is
The royal disposition of that beast
To prey on nothing, that doth seem as dead:
This seen, Orlando did approach the man,
And found it was his brother, his elder brother.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l:
O I have heard him speak
of that same brother,
And he did render him the most unnatural
That lived amongst men.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: And well he might so do,
For well I know he was unnatural.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But to Orlando: did he leave him there
Food to the sucked and hungry Lioness?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Twice did he turn his back, and purposed so:
But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
And Nature stronger than his just occasion,
Made him give battle to the Lioness:
Who quickly fell before him, in which hurtling
From miserable slumber I awaked.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are you his brother?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Was it you he rescued?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Was it you that did so oft contrive to kill him?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: It was I: but it is not I: I do not shame
To tell you what I was, since my conversion
So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But for the bloody napkin?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: By and by:
When from the first to last betwixt us two,
Tears our recountments had most kindly bathed,
As how I came into that Desert place.
I brief, he led me to the gentle Duke,
Who gave me fresh array, and entertainment,
Committing me unto my brothers love,
Who led me instantly unto his Cave,
There stripped himself, and here upon his arm
The Lioness had torn some flesh away,
Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted,
And cried in fainting upon Rosalinde.
Brief, I recovered him, bound up his wound,
And after some small space, being strong at heart,
He sent me hither, stranger as I am
To tell this story, that you might excuse
His broken promise, and to give this napkin
Died in this blood, unto the Shepherd youth,
That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why how now Ganimed, sweet Ganimed.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is more in it; Cousin Ganimed.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Look, he recovers.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I would I were at home.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: We will lead you thither:
I pray you will you take him by the arm.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Be of good cheer youth: you a man?
You lack a man's heart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I do so, I confess it:
Ah, sirrah, a body would think this was well counterfeited,
I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited:
heigh-ho.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
This was not counterfeit, there is too great testimony
in your complexion that it was a passion of earnest.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Counterfeit, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Well then, take a good heart, and counterfeit to
be a man.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
So I do: but i'faith, I should have been a woman
by right.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Come, you look paler and paler: pray you draw
homewards: good sir, go with us

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
That will I: for I must bear answer back
How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I shall devise something: but I pray you commend
my counterfeiting to him: will you go?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
We shall find a time Awdrie, patience gentle
Awdrie.

sp.speaker: Awd.
sp.p:
Faith the Priest was good enough, for all the
old gentleman's saying.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
A most wicked Sir Oliuer, Awdrie, a most vile
Mar text. But Awdrie, there is a youth here in the
Forest lays claim to you.

sp.speaker: Awd.
sp.p:
Aye, I know who it is: he hath no interest in me
in the world: here comes the man you mean.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
It is meat and drink to me to see a Clown, by
my troth, we that have good wits, have much to answer
for: we shall be flouting: we cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Good even Audrey.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: God ye good even William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And good even to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Good even gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover
thy head: Nay prithee be covered. How old are you
Friend?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Five and twenty Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A ripe age: Is thy name William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: William, sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A fair name. Wast born in the Forest here?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aye sir, I thank God.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Thank God: A good answer:
Art rich?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I'faith sir, so, so.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
So, so, is good, very good, very excellent good:
and yet it is not, it is but so, so:
Art thou wise?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: aye sir, I have a pretty wit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, thou sayst well. I do now remember a saying:
The Fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man
knows himself to be a Fool. The Heathen Philosopher,
when he had a desire to eat a Grape, would open
his lips when he put it into his mouth, meaning thereby,
that Grapes were made to eat, and lips to open.
You do love this maid?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I do sit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Give me your hand: Art thou Learned?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Then learn this of me, To have, is to have. For
it is a figure in Rhetoric, that drink being poured out
of a cup into a glass, by filling the one, doth empty the
other. For all your Writers do consent, that ipse is he:
now you are not ipse, for I am he.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Which he sir?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
He sir, that must marry this woman: Therefore
you Clown, abandon: which is in the vulgar, leave the
society: which in the boorish, is company, of this female:
which in the common, is woman: which together,
is, abandon the society of this Female, or Clown
thou perishest: or to thy better understanding, diest; or
(to wit) I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into
death, thy liberty into bondage: I will deal in poison
with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel: I will bandy
with thee in faction, I will overrun thee with police: I
will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways, therefore tremble
and depart.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Do good William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: God rest you merry sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Our Master and Mistress seeks you: come away,
away.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Trip Audry, trip Audry, I attend,
I attend.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Is it possible, that on so little acquaintance you
should like her? that, but seeing, you should love her?
And loving woo? and wooing, she should grant? And
will you persevere to enjoy her?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Neither call the giddiness of it in question; the
poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing,
nor sudden consenting: but say with me, I love
Aliena: say with her, that she loves me; consent with
both, that we may enjoy each other: it shall be to your
good: for my fathers house, and all the revenue, that
was old Sir Rowlands will I estate upon you, and here
live and die a Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You have my consent.
Let your Wedding be tomorrow: thither will I
Invite the Duke, and all his contented followers:
Go you, and prepare Aliena; for look you,
Here comes my Rosalinde.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: God save you brother.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And you fair sister.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
O my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see
thee wear thy heart in a scarf.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: It is my arm.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I thought thy heart had been wounded with
the claws of a Lion.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited
to sound, when he showed me your handkercher?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Aye, and greater wonders than that.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
O, I know where you are: nay, it is true: there
was never anything so sudden, but the fight of two
Rams, and Cesars Thrasonicall brag of I came, saw,
and overcome. For your brother, and my sister, no sooner
met, but they looked; no sooner looked, but they
loved; no sooner loved, but they sighed: no sooner sighed
but they asked one another the reason: no sooner knew
the reason, but they sought the remedy: and in these
degrees, have they made a pair of stairs to marriage,
which they will climb incontinent, or else be incontinent
before marriage; they are in the very wrath of
love, and they will together. Clubs cannot part
them.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
They shall be married tomorrow: and I will
bid the Duke to the Nuptial. But O, how bitter a thing
it is, to look into happiness through another man's eyes:
by so much the more shall I tomorrow be at the height
of heart heaviness. by how much I shall think my brother
happy, in having what he wishes for.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Why then tomorrow, I cannot serve your turn
for Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I can live no longer by thinking.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.
Know of me then (for now I speak to some purpose)
that I know you are a Gentleman of good conceit:
I speak not this, that you should bear a good opinion
of my knowledge: insomuch (I say) I know you are: neither
do I labour for a greater esteem then may in some
little measure draw a belief from you, to do yourself
good, and not to grace me. Believe then, if you please,
that I can do strange things: I have since I was three
year old conversed with a Magician, most profound in
his Art, and yet not damnable. If you do love Rosalinde
so near the hart, as your gesture cries it out: when your
brother marries Aliena, shall you marry her. I know into
what straights of Fortune she is driven, and it is not
impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you,
to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is,
and without any danger.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Speakest thou in sober meanings?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
By my life I do, which I tender dearly, though
I say I am a Magician: Therefore put you in your best array,
bid you friends: for if you will be married tomorrow,
you shall: and to Rosalind if you will.
Look, here comes a Lover of mine, and a lover of hers.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness,
To show the letter that I writ to you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I care not if I have: it is my study
To seem despiteful and ungentle to you:
you are there followed by a faithful shepherd,
Look upon him, love him: he worships you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Good shepherd, tell this youth what it is to love

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is to be all made of sighs and tears,
And so am I for Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And I for Ganimed.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: And I for Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros
sp.l: And I for no woman.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is to be all made of faith and service,
And so am I for Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And I for Ganimed.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: And I for Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros
sp.l: And I for no woman.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is to be all made of fantasy,
All made of passion, and all made of wishes,
All adoration, duty, and observance,
All humbleness, all patience, and impatience,
All purity, all trial, and observance:
And so am I for Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And so am I for Ganimed.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: And so am I for Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And so am I for no woman.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Why do you speak too, Why blame you me
to love you.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: To her, that is not here, nor doth not hear.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Pray you no more of this, it is like the howling
of Irish Wolves against the Moon: I will help you
if I can: I would love you if I could: tomorrow meet
me altogether: I will marry you, if ever I marry Woman,
and I will be married tomorrow: I will satisfy you,
if ever I satisfied man, and you shall be married tomorrow
I will content you, if what pleases you contents
you, and you shall be married tomorrow: As you love
Rosalind meet, as you love Phebe meet, and as I love no
woman, I will meet: so fare you well: I have left you commands.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I will not fail, if I live.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Tomorrow is the joyful day Audrey, tomorrow
will we be married.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p:
I do desire it with all my heart: and I hope it is
no dishonest desire, to desire to be a woman of the world? Here come two of the banished Dukes Pages.

sp.speaker: 1. Pa.
sp.p: Well met honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: By my troth well met: come, sit, sit, and a song.

sp.speaker: 2. Pa.
sp.p: We are for you, sit in the middle.

sp.speaker: 1. Pa.
sp.p:
Shall we clap into it roundly, without hawking,
or spitting, or saying we are hoarse, which are the only
prologues to a bad voice.

sp.speaker: 2. Pa.
sp.p:
Aye faith, i'faith and both in a tune like two
gypsies on a horse.

sp.l: It was a Lover, and his lass,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
That over the green corn field did pass,
In the spring time, the only pretty rang time.
When Birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding.
Sweet Lovers love the spring,
And therefore take the present time.
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
For love is crowned with the prime.
In spring time, etcetera
Between the acres of the Rye,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino:
These pretty Country folks would lie.
In spring time, etcetera
This Carroll they began that hour,
With a hey and a ho, and a hey nonino:
How that a life was but a Flower,
In Spring time, etcetera

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly young Gentlemen, though there was no
great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untunable

sp.speaker: 1. Pa.
sp.p:
you are deceived Sir, we kept time, we lost not
our time.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth yes: I count it but time lost to hear
such a foolish song. God buy you, and God mend your
voices. Come Audrie.

div2.head: Scena Quarta.
div2.stage: Enter Duke Senior, Amyens, Iaques, Orlando, Oliuer, Celia.

sp.speaker: Du. Sen.
sp.l: Dost thou believe Orlando, that the boy
Can do all this that he hath promised?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I sometimes do believe, and sometimes do not,
As those that fear they hope, and know they fear.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Patience once more, whiles our compact is urged:
You say, if I bring in your Rosalinde,
You will bestow her on Orlando here?

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.l: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And you say you will have her, when I bring her?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: That would I, were I of all kingdoms King.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You say, you will marry me, if I be willing.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: That will I, should I die the hour after.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But if you do refuse to marry me,
You will give yourself to this most faithful Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: So is the bargain.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You say that you will have Phebe if she will.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Though to have her and death, were both one thing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I have promised to make all this matter even:
Keep you your word, O Duke, to give your daughter,
You yours Orlando, to receive his daughter:
Keep you your word Phebe, that you will marry me,
Or else refusing me to wed this shepherd:
Keep your word Siluius, that you will marry her
If she refuse me, and from hence I go
To make these doubts all even.

sp.speaker: Du. Sen.
sp.l: I do remember in this shepherd boy,
Some lively touches of my daughters favour.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: My Lord, the first time that I ever saw him,
Methought he was a brother to your daughter:
But my good Lord, this Boy is Forest born,
And hath been tutored in the rudiments
Of many desperate studies, by his uncle,
Whom he reports to be a great Magician.
Obscured in the circle of this Forest.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
There is sure another flood toward, and these
couples are coming to the Ark. Here comes a pair
of very strange beasts, which in all tongues, are called
Fools.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Salutation and greeting to you all.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Good my Lord, bid him welcome: This is the
Motley-minded Gentleman, that I have so often met in
the Forest: he hath been a Courtier he swears.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If any man doubt that, let him put me to my
purgation, I have trod a measure, I have flattered a Lady,
I have been politic with my friend, smooth with mine
enemy, I have undone three Tailors, I have had four
quarrels, and like to have fought one.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And how was that taken up?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I'faith we met, and found the quarrel was upon
the seventh cause.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
How seventh cause? Good my Lord, like this
fellow.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.p: I like him very well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
God'ild you sir, I desire you of the like: I press
in here sir, amongst the rest of the Country copulatives
to swear, and to forswear, according as marriage binds
and blood breaks: a poor virgin sir, an ill-favoured thing
sir, but mine own, a poor humour of mine sir, to take
that that no man else will: rich honesty dwells like a miser
sir, in a poor house, as your Pearl in your foul oyster.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.p: By my faith, he is very swift, and sententious.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
According to the fools bolt sir, and such dulcet
diseases.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
But for the seventh cause. How did you find
the quarrel on the seventh cause?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Upon a lie, seven times removed: (bear your
body more seeming Audry ) as thus sir: I did dislike the
cut of a certain Courtiers beard: he sent me word, if I
said his beard was not cut well, he was in the mind it
was: this is called the retort courteous. If I sent him
word again, it was not well cut, he would send me word
he cut it to please himself: this is called the quip modest.
If again, it was not well cut, he disabled my judgment:
this is called, the reply churlish. If again it was not well
cut, he would answer I spake not true: this is called the
reproof valiant. If again, it was not well cut, he would
say, I lie: this is called the countercheck quarrelsome:
and so to the lie circumstantial, and the lie direct.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
And how oft did you say his beard was not well
cut?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I durst go no further than the lie circumstantial:
nor he durst not give me the lie direct: and so we measured
swords, and parted.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Can you nominate in order now, the degrees of
the lie.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O sir, we quarrel in print, by the book: as you
have books for good manners: I will name you the degrees.
The first, the Retort courteous: the second, the
Quip-modest: the third, the reply Churlish: the fourth,
the Reproof valiant: the fifth, the Countercheck quarrelsome:
the sixth, the Lie with circumstance: the seventh,
the Lie direct: all these you may avoid, but the
Lie direct: and you may avoid that too, with an If. I
knew when seven Justices could not take up a Quarrel,
but when the parties were met themselves, one of them
thought but of an If; as if you said so, then I said so:
and they shook hands, and swore brothers. Your If, is
the only peace-maker: much virtue in if.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Is not this a rare fellow my Lord? He is as good
at anything and yet a fool.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.p:
He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under
the presentation of that he shoots his wit.

div2.stage: Enter Hymen, Rosalind, and Celia. Still Musicke.

sp.speaker: Hymen.
sp.l: Then is there mirth in heaven,
When earthly things made even
atone together.
Good Duke receive thy daughter,
Hymen from Heaven brought her,
Yea brought her hither.
That thou mightst join his hand with his,
Whose heart within his bosom is.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: To you I give myself, for I am yours.
To you I give myself, for I am yours.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.l: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: If sight and shape be true, why then my love adieu

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I will have no Father, if you be not he:
I will have no Husband, if you be not he:
Nor never wed woman, if you be not she.

sp.speaker: Hy.
sp.l: Peace ho: I bar confusion,
It is I must make conclusion
Of these most strange events:
Here is eight that must take hands,
To join in Hymens bands,
If truth holds true contents.
You and you, no cross shall part;
You and you, are hart in hart:
You, to his love must accord,
Or have a Woman to your Lord.
You and you, are sure together,
As the Winter to foul Weather:
Whiles a Wedlock Hymn we sing,
Feed yourselves with questioning:
That reason, wonder may diminish
How thus we met, and these things finish.
Wedding is great Iunos crown,
O blessed bond of board and bed:
It is Hymen peoples every town,
High wedlock then be honoured:
Honour, high honour and renown
To Hymen, God of every Town.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.l: O my dear Niece, welcome thou art to me,
Even daughter welcome, in no less degree.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: I will not eat my word, now thou art mine,
Thy faith, my fancy to thee doth combine.

sp.speaker: 2. Bro.
sp.l: Let me have audience for a word or two:
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Duke Frederick hearing how that every day
Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
Addressed a mighty power, which were on foot
In his own conduct, purposely to take
His brother here, and put him to the sword:
And to the skirts of this wild Wood he came;
Where, meeting with an old Religious man,
After some question with him, was converted
Both from his enterprise, and from the world:
His crown bequeathing to his banished Brother,
And all their Lands restored to him again
That were with him exiled. This to be true,
I do engage my life.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.l: Welcome young man:
Thou offerest fairly to thy brothers wedding:
To one his lands with-held, and to the other
A land itself at large, a potent Dukedom.
First, in this Forest, let us do those ends
That here were well begun, and well begot:
And after, every of this happy number
That have endured shrewd days, and nights with us,
Shall share the good of our returned fortune,
According to the measure of their states.
Mean time, forget this new fallen dignity,
And fall into our Rustic Revelry:
Play Music, and you Brides and Bridegrooms all,
With measure heaped in joy, to the Measures fall.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Sir, by your patience: if I heard you rightly,
The Duke hath put on a Religious life,
And thrown into neglect the pompous Court.

sp.speaker: 2. Bro.
sp.l: He hath.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: To him will I: out of these convertites,
There is much matter to be heard, and learned:
you to your former Honour, I bequeath
your patience, and your virtue, well deserves it.
you to a love, that your true faith doth merit:
you to your land, and love, and great allies:
you to a long, and well-deserved bed:
And you to wrangling, for thy loving voyage
Is but for two months victualled: So to your pleasures,
I am for other, then for dancing measures.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.l: Stay, Iaques, stay.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: To see no pastime, I: what you would have,
I will stay to know, at your abandoned cave.

sp.speaker: Du. Se.
sp.l: Proceed, proceed: we will begin these rights,
As we do trust, they will end in true delights.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
It is not the fashion to see the Lady the Epilogue:
but it is no more unhandsome than to see the
Lord the Prologue. If it be true, that good wine needs
no bush, it is true, that a good play needs no Epilogue.
Yet to good wine they do use good bushes: and good
plays prove the better by the help of good Epilogues:
What a case am I in then, that am neither a good Epilogue,
nor cannot insinuate with you in the behalf of a
good play? I am not furnished like a Beggar, therefore
to beg will not become me. My way is to conjure
you, and I will begin with the Women. I charge you (O
women) for the love you bear to men, to like as much
of this Play, as please you: And I charge you (O men)
for the love you bear to women (as I perceive by your
simpering, none of you hates them) that between you,
and the women, the play may please. If I were a Woman,
I would kiss as many of you as had beards that
pleased me, complexions that liked me, and breaths that
I defied not: And I am sure, as many as have good
beards, or good faces, or sweet breaths, will for my kind
offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.
